I have 1/4" boro and a pei sheet on top of that. No warpage at all with long ABS. I am getting layer delaminization now on the upper layers with ABS hence the need for an enclosure to keep the heat in on larger tall ABS prints, like sun shades for tablets / phones.

title: THE Tweezer strain relief
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: THE Tweezer prints very well in standard ABS, but my print in antistatic ABS was splitting at the apex of the loop; that material is considerably more brittle than standard ABS. I tried a layered print, with standard ABS on the top 1/4. It worked, but it's not solidly ESD-safe. This support, which goes on the loop part, relieves stress on the loop. Props to Fredsena, the original designer.

Build with sufficient strength (2+ layers, 25%+ infill suggested).  Snap this down from the top; this allows THE Tweezer to lie flat.  I used a little Acetone to make paste out of the AS ABS scrap to glue it in place; it's not absolutely necessary.

title: Dropping Eggs from Drones for Fun and Science - The Claw Egg Drop Mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I was invited by a local school to participate in their Egg-Drop science event and this is one of the results. The reason they invited me was because they wanted to do something different this year. Instead of dropping boxes to protect contained eggs they wanted to drop eggs from a drone or multirotor and try to catch and protect the eggs. The first iteration of the concept was this claw-type mechanism to drop one egg at a time. I modified the snap mounting from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745817 (Thank you glenchung!) to hold a servo. Assembly requires a miniservo and a bit of solid core wire or we hot glued part of a zip tie to the servo arm. I had planed to use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28566 to create a custom servo arm but moved to a more complicated Rotary Egg Dropper instead. Check it out here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:859220/ More information at Instructables.com (http://www.instructables.com/id/Dropping-eggs-from-drones-for-fun-and-science/)

I printed in PLA with two perimeters, two bottom layers, two top layers, no support and 15% infill. The result needed some filing in order to fit the servo and to snap to the Iris+ arm. I never ended up screwing the servo in place because it was a snug enough without help.  
The picture of the clip mounted to the Iris is of our "practice egg".  Don't use i-hooks on real eggs and don't test fit with real eggs either.  For the event I used a couple inches of electrical tape to make a loop on top of the eggs for the claw to grip.

author: GabriPoma

title: Lulzbot 2.8W Laser Upgrade Mount - J Tech Photonics

description.text:
This is the mount for upgrading your Lulzbot printer as a laser machine by removing the extruder to get the most space on the platform. For full instructions with pictures go to: http://jtechphotonics.com/?p=2440 Some videos of laser capabilities:
Image engraving: https://youtu.be/-DyqshA7Jn4
Cutting Acrylic: https://youtu.be/NV5NWtxTdn4

Electronics We are going to use the fan1 connection on the Rambo board to control the laser. It has PWM control needed to do picture engraving and is easily controlled with M106/107 commands in software. We decided to remove the extruder assembly to get more room for the laser on the worksurface, but left the actual extruder on the Z axis because the firmware looks for it on startup. We choose to mount the driver on the side of the enclosure because the enclosure is full of electronics already and it is easily accessable for the key switch and power controls without having to put more holes in the alluminum. We routed the laser and fan cables through the enclosure and up the wiring harness chain to the Z axis and made it all nice and tidy. Mechanical We made a mount to fit using the screws that attached to the extruder assembly we removed. It allows the laser to point down on the work surface and have the same position as the old extruder. This gave the maximum table size for the laser without having to limit anything. The fan upgrade kit fits on the back of the laser and nothing was needed for modification. We also removed the glass table and replaced it with a 6″ x 6″ piece of aluminum we bought from Amazon small parts. Considering the laser can burn through the glass surface, we choose to put an aluminum bed instead. We made small mounting holders for each of the corners to keep the aluminum held down to the table. It would be better to make a piece of aluminum to fit that is 7″ x 7″ but we didn’t have the time to cut a piece ourselves due to our CNC being unassembled (more on that later). Here is a link to the mounting holders: Software We had to modify the firmware of the Lulzbot because the PWM frequency was set way to high for it to control the laser. You can get the firmware from Lulzbot here: Lulzbot Firmware You need to load all of the files into your Arduino compiler and make a new sketch that shows all of the files. Make sure you have the newest version of the compiler downloaded from Arduino HERE. Set you board as Arduino Mega or Mega 2560 . Then in config.h, comment out the line: //#define FAST_PWM_FAN Then make sure your are connected to the correct COM port and the printer is connected to the computer and compile the firmware. You are now done! We used Repetier Host to control the printer. We like the “preview” feature for the G Code and it does a good job with everything else as well. You need to adjust some of the settings because the table will be slightly smaller.

  • Open the Box. I like that it says Open on the top…

  • Print out the little tab for the aluminum plate on the bed. Total of 4.

  • Place the tabs on top of the aluminum plate. Remember, you only need this if you bought the 6″ x 6″ aluminum sheet.

  • Screw on the top metal circle to hold the plate down on all four sides.

  • Take off the extruder assembly. Three screws from the back side and uplug it from the top connector.

  • Take off the fan.

  • Take off the nozzle attachment.

  • Remove the extruder motor assembly with two screws shown on each side of the extruder.

  • Mount the laser mount using the extruder screws in the laser step. Mount the laser to the mount and also the fan upgrade mount.

  • Cut the motor cable and put extruder motor assembly aside. Keep the extruder and zip tie it in place. Route the cables up and through the back wire chain.
    • 10 attach extruder next to laser with zip ties

  • screw down the top after the wires are routed.

  • Open the electronics enclosure.

  • We will be using the FAN1 connection to connect the laser. It is the Black and White cable.

  • Put wires into enclosure and zip tie on the cable chain.

  • Pull wires through into the enclosure.

    1. Replace fan cable with new cable to laser driver. We cut our fan cable and soldered a longer cable onto the original connector.

    2. Drill holes to mount the laser driver board on the outside of the enclosure. Drill one, then put the driver board up and mark the rest to line it up.

  • Drill larger hole for laser, fan, and control cables to the laser driver board and route.

  • Mount the laser driver and connect the laser, fan, and control cables.

    1. Open the Arduino SW and load the Marlin Mini firmware. In config.h, comment out the line FAST_PWM_FAN like in the picture. You can also use SW PWM, but make sure it is not above 5KHz.
  • All done and ready to engrave and cut!

title: Laser Fan Mount 40mm - J Tech Photonics Laser Upgrade

description.text: This is the fan mount we offer on our laser upgrade kits. Feel free to print it out and mount your own fan rather than buying the assembled version from us. Keeping your laser cool is very important and it also provides a way to keep smoke and debris off the lens. This one is shown mounted on a PrintRBot. For more information go to: http://www.jtechphotonics.com

Use any 40mm fan. You can find them at http://Digikey.com or Amazon.com or your local electronics/hardware store. Attach the fan with it pushing air towards the laser. Use any bolt and nut that fits for the fan, we prefer using 6/32 5/8" screws because they are inexpensive. To mount the laser, use two more 6/32 screws and nuts.

I scaled it back down and added that file as well as the first one. Simple hook I designed for my Daughter to hang Lithopanes she prints on her window. Stick to the window with double sided tape or putty meant for hanging stuff on windows.
I would not trim the tape first. apply a square big enough and then trim the extra with an exacto, that way you don't take a chance of getting oils on the tape. Might want to wipe the glass with acetone as well. As alawys no license regardless of what it says to the right

description.text:
Smoothly molded from space-age plastics, this retro-styled rocket ship displays the clean, smooth lines one expects from a classic, but with the bolted-on "cone" one expects from Victorian engineering. The protuberant hatch allows easy egress, and the wing pods are socketed to allow easy attachment of accessories.  
Redesigned from the ground up, this rocket features evenly distributed "wings" with engines mounted at the end of each. The engine shields on the main thruster protect it from debris getting sucked in when it cycles during power up and help to focus the raw energies to improve propulsion.

This retro-rocketship is designed to print without supports or raft. As pictured, it was printed at 0.3mm for speed and 30% infill using PLA directly on acrylic. When detaching, start with the three wings, then the center.

Got bike disc brakes? Then you need to print this this. This is needed for travelling without your wheels in place, but with the pad spacer. It protects brake pads from stacking in a case of accidental squeezing of the lever with the wheel out. Without it that could cause necessarity of complete disassembling all brake system. More info http://www.bikeradar.com/mtb/gear/article/home-wrench-disc-brake-tools-and-tricks-42505/ Это специальная вставка для обладателей дисковых тормозов на велосипеде. При транспортировке со снятыми колесам необходимо ставить такой вкладыш в колодки, иначе при случайном нажатии на ручку тормоза без колеса можно попасть на полную переборку тормозов.

The BrakePad01.stl is simply pair of Things. The BrakePad03.stl is the file with same Things, but special support is added. It protects the nose from coming off the table while printing on the glass on several printers.

description.text: Printed this to replace a broken key head for a 2000 Honda Civic. I uploaded the pre-cutout file in case you want to change the design. The honda logo was maybe a little too small for my printer.

Printed on a Zortrax M200 at .14 layer height, solid fill.  I paused my printer the layer before it added the top and rammed the key in (it was a smidge too small so I heated it up with a heat gun to get it to fit) My printer had a hard time printing on the metal of the key so I did a few more pauses to flatten stuff down (with a heated spatula). It eventually came around after a few layers though.

title: Proof of Concept Ratcheting Drum for Test Jig #2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a proof of concept ratcheting drum for syvwlch's Test Jig #2 which can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8275 It is meant to simplify the re-winding of the string on the clock's drum without dis-assembling the jig. Being an experiment and proof of concept, it isn't particularly parametric at this time, but should serve as a useful starting point for integration into the clockwork libs or other adaptations.

Updates:
2011-05-16 - The uploaded STL file for the drum had a strange problem with the arms being mis-placed. It has been replaced with a correct version.
Print the two parts, snap together, replace existing drum in the test jig.

comments.text: Anyone else having an issue with the reversal tool making the extruder vomit everywhere on the first layer of the gear?

comments.text: tempting... but I'm not sure the cupcake would survive the fall   :-P
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Although it seems that theres an issue with the second STL, the drum, there's a gap under the ratchet arms. I'm a I missing something?

comments.text: Welcome back! We're preparing a new release that takes all that we have learned with Test Jig #2 and applies it to an actual clock. Hope to put that up soon... we'll need testers and people publishing mods like this one. :-)
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: I have a spool of the original natural PLA makerbot sold. I'll try out a few alternatives with it to see if we can solve the breakage issues.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: That is a thing of beauty!
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Oh, and I closed the How-to-wind-the-clock issue on GitHub. Thanks. :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: We may want to keep it open or open a new one. This is only a partial solution. While it can be driven by hand, it assumes the drum is readily accessible to a hand. We probably want to add another gear to the drum which would interface with a second gear which would interface with a removable "key" that can be turned to wind the clock. This should provide a way to wind the drum on a more finished version of the clock with a mostly closed clock face.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: If you replace the last gear in the gear train (fully exposed, furthest back, and the pinion teeth are unused) with this gear then that shouldn't be a problem, you could just design a key that could act directly on this drum.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I was thinking, actually, that we could take a page from the old grandfather clocks and have the string keep winding around the drum past the point where it is attached, and hang  down from the other side of the drum.
comments.author: NateH

comments.text: Not that we can't open an issue to create a key-driven winding system too. :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: I like the string winder idea, it keeps things simple for now. The key driven approach could be considered a nice to have. I'm thinking it might be necessary to partition the drum so the winding string doesn't overlap the unwinding string. I'll do some tests later today (with video) to see how it works with the drum as-is.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Re: string around the drum with 2 weights. Might just need a deeper drum, then with a suitably sized string it will find its own path (and shouldn't pile up) and walk from one end of the drum to the other. It just depends on how long the string is vs the circumference of the drum.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: We might also need a small counter-weight on the free end of the string so it stays out of the way.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: Yeah, my next derivative was going to be parametric weight and counter-weight containers for coins.
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Can we see some video? Pretty please? :-)
comments.author: syvwlch

comments.text: Think this will work in PLA?
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: I don't see why not. If the arms are too stiff, reducing their height should reduce the stiffness in the narrow section of the arm.
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: The ends of the arms only have to move ~1mm, to get over the tip of the ratchet tooth.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: cool, I'm gonna get the machine going and see how it works as is in PLA then :)
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: having printed the spring part in PLA, I think we're good. the arms are springy enough it should work well.  Printing the gear now.
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: Awesome!
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: Gah, take that back.  One of the arms snapped right off on the first turn.  PLA may just be too rigid to print these kind of springs.  I'm gonna try and make em a bit thinner so theres more area that can flex (right now it's all one spot).
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: They will need to be thin but tall. Short and they will still be stiff, thin will be flexible. It might also pay to make them longer, curving round from another 90 degrees around the drum maybe. Makes the bridges a bit harder to print, but might allow enough flew that way.
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: Maybe instead make a PLA version with hinged levers that have a rubber band wrapped around a short back end?  More complex, and maybe bigger drum to acomodate it, but perhaps greater reliability?
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: This may be what I end up doing.  So far I've printed 3 different designs, all of which snapped.  PLA just doesn't like to bend.
comments.author: ssd

comments.text: PLA does bend, just not much. Whats the longest arm you have tried? I'd try and modify my own version, but OpenSCAD scares me.
comments.author: pipakin

comments.text: The longest i've tried is only whats seen in the pics. Given that I almost exclusively work in ABS (I have 10x as many problems getting PLA to cooperate) the first design worked so I went with it. I'll switch to PLA for a bit (and suffer the horrors) to see if I can find something workable. probably a longer, possibly curved arm. I'm thinking the most important part will be to have the narrowest width be as long as possible to distribute the flexing across more of the arm. That way all the flexing isn't concentrated in a single point which seems to be the issue (per pipakin).
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: I work exclusively in PLA and have no extruder issues with it, to save youself the pain of switching I can print stuff if you want.
comments.author: rustedrobot

comments.text: I didn't modify the length that much, so that very well might work.  I also had a few issues with my printer so that may have contributed.  I'm excited that I inspired some thought :)
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: An alternative might be to make the ratchet work axially, with two interlocking saw-tooth ratchets that are gently pushed together by a single metal spring slipped over the shaft, and compressed between the top of the drum and the frame of the clock.
comments.author: pipakin

title: 3D printing + sugru = precision rubber parts - iPhone 4/4S or 5 molds

description.text:
Print your own desktop manufacturing kit to produce precision rubber parts directly onto the iPhone 4/4S or iPhone 5 with sugru. There are 2 sets of molds here: 1 set for the iPhone 4/4S and another set for the iPhone 5. Each set has 3 components (make sure you print them all) You will also need a set of nuts and bolts:
Metric: 8 x M5 x 25mm bolts + washers and wing nuts.
Imperial: 8 x 10/32 x 1" bolts + washers and wing nuts. UPDATE - 17th May - We've just uploaded a new set of molds with an improved draft angle for better release. Please download, edit and create the molds as you wish. If you think you can push this technique further, we're giving free sugru to the very best ideas. What would you like to try? Get in touch touch via email to [email protected]

Watch our tutorial about how to use this mold at the end of this short Introduction video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lphVVWNYZnY Follow our step by step guide here: Get your maker mits on sugru here: sugru.com/buy

comments.text: What exactly does this thing do??
comments.author: eric_acr

comments.text: Hello Eric. This is a compression mould design that allows you to produce precision rubber bumpers on the iPhone 4 and 4S. If you watch the video you should see how it works. Hope this helps. James
comments.author: eric_acr

comments.text: UPDATE 17th May - We've just uploaded a new set of molds with an improved draft angle for better release. If you've downloaded the previous version, let us know how you've got and how you think we can improve.

comments.text: Keep up the good work, Sugru! :-)

comments.text: Even better, don't use Sugru (because it's expensive) and instead use "Oogoo" - it's a mixture of silicone caulk + corn starch.  The corn starch impressively speeds up curing time of the silicone and makes a perfect substitute for Sugru

author: kevinrau

description.text:
I noticed some dragging on my Taz 5 spool arm. I didnt like anyone elses ideas I found online. I really like the stock mounting location on the Taz and I like how it pivots a little. So I cut up a taz arm and combined it with the idea "mde091234" had going of using a screw rod. My screw rod is a little bigger than 7mm. it fits nicely in the 608z bearings i have. i have 2 washer, 1 nut, and 1 locking nylon nut. a wing nut would be nice to substitute the outside nut. you will need the rod, and 4 bearings (608Z) i dont know the difference between 608Z and 608ZZ that the other user was using. Grabbed part of my spool arm from Lulzbot
http://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0/production_parts/printed_parts/ I grabbed the spool cone from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:257366/#files

I printed this in ABS and it came out great. the natural shrinkage worked out really well. I was able to thread the rod onto the arm part and then secured it with the locking nut. it wasnt going anywhere after that. I placed a washer on the rod next and put the inner spool cone on and secured it with a regular nut. When I was loading the bearings into the spool cones, they were a nice snug fit. I loaded the next spool cone on, then a washer and finally the last nut. preferably you should use a wing nut here but i didnt have one available.

description.text:

Balls are 9,5mm steel balls: http://www.ebay.com/itm/BALL-BEARINGS-9-5MM-3-8-PACK-X-100-/200970728122?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item2ecac9f2ba Optional:
There is a motor mount and gears if you want to add a motor
There is a hole in the motor box for a DC connector.
Micro Gearmotor 75:1 3V: https://www.pololu.com/product/2366
DC connector: http://comingsoon.radioshack.com/size-n-coaxial-dc-power-jack-w-switch/2741583.html#.VWjWWs_tlBc Let me know if you want a battery box instead of the DC connector.

description.text: A small PCB that breaks out SSOP-08 packages to a standard 0.1" pin spacing. This allows you to use these SMD devices with bread boards and strip boards. I created this board so that I could use a PCA9306 I<sup >2</sup>C level shifter in a prototype, but it'll work with any SSOP-08 device.

Use EagleCAD (http://www.cadsoft.de/) to load and print out the PCB design. Alternatively, download the 10 way PNG file and print at 600dpi. Use your PCB transfer and manufacturing process of your choosing to fabricate the circuit board. I used a photo-resistive board with UV exposure. The board was then developed, etched and stripped. Drill out the 8 holes for the bin headers. Position your SSOP-8 package on the board and solder in place. I used solder paste and a hot air reflow tool. Solder in the pin headers. Verify that you don't have any shorts or bridges electrically with a multi-meter, and visually with a magnifier.
Bought the wrong blades? Look no further, here's a handle for the Mach3 blades.

Print it standing. Put the blade on the handle until it wont go any further. Problem solving:
Blade wont fit: try lowering the flow rate or extruder width. Blade falls of: try a higher flow rate or a wider extruder width.

title: Tripod cam-lock repair for Manfrotto 785b Modo

description.text:
The cam-locks on my Manfrotto 785b Modo suddenly started to crack and break, both locks on the second section (counting from the bottom). Apparently this is a known weakness of this (cheap) plastic locks, also on other types of Manfrotto tripods. Instead of throwing it away, I decided to make a replacement part in ABS.   
The ABS should resist forces better than the plastic that was used before, but hey, time will tell.

I prepared the print with slic3r, using the support material option. It took some extra time to remove the supports, but it gave me a nice result on the overhanging parts, even from the very first print.   
To remove the original camlocks, first push out the brass pin with a hammer and drift. Then take out the small rectangular block that locks the shaft. Now you should be able to remove the lock, make sure you don't lose the small parts that fall out.

metaPixel is a simple, modular WS2812 LED-strip base LED panel. Each module contains 20 LEDs in a 4x5 grid behind a printed diffusor. The modules are connected by D-SUB high power connectors. Magnets on the sides of the modules add stability to the connection. I have used black ABS for the boxes and clear colorfabb XT for the diffusor foil. Autodesk Fusion archives and STEP files are included in the zip archive. controlled by a Teensy 3.1 using the FastLED library. Videos: In action, Parts Additional sources (Software, Schematics etc.) on github

For each module, you will need:
  • 1 x Diffusor + Grid either a full transparent (single piece) or glued together from grid and foil.
  • 1 x Cover
  • 1 x Box (there a 5 different versions differing in the position of the connectors)
  • 3 x D-SUB, High Power jack
  • 3 x D-SUB High Power plug
  • 4 x round magnets 3x3
  • 4 x round magnets 4x3
  • 3 to 6 x ring magnets 6/2,2
  • 4 x magnets 5x8
  • 20 x WS2812 LED from a 60LED/m strip.
  • wires
  • glue to fixate the magnets and to glue the translucent diffusor to the opaque grid (if used)
    • For the full display you'll need a sufficient 5V power supply and a custom programmed controller. A commercial controller will not work as expected because the LED layout changes with each metaPixel row (see CableLayout MetaPixel.pdf).

• mark the same pole on all magnets with a marker. This will save a lot of work. In is merely impossible to remove a false positioned magnet after it is glued in.
  • glue in all the magnets use the CableLayout-MetaPixel.pdf as a reference.

Originally designed to keep mouse cords in line and on desk, this multi-part object has been realized for its true potential. It can be attached to the side of a tall desk to keep cords in line or on track, on the bottom of a laptop table (as shown in photos 2-4) to keep bundles of peripheral cords out of sight, or even as a creative way to hang keys on a wall. No matter what way you use it, you're using it right. Presently Available Versions:
1x0.5 inch base Enclosure Model (V1) More shapes, sizes, versions, and photos to come; check back often.

Because the holes in Part 2's of Enclosure Models are designed to be the exact circumference of the pegs in Part 1's of Enclosure Models, and 3D printers are, sadly, imperfect machines, some sanding on the pegs of Part 1's are required. Do not sand the thicker part of the pegs, but rather the skinnier part towards the top. Sand until the Part 2's will fit firmly and snugly. You want quite a bit of friction, otherwise the enclosure will not work. A well put together Model should snap when shutting the enclosure. If you have sanded the pegs and the Part 2's will still not fit, ensure that the holes of the Part 2's are clear and free of printing errors.

A holder (mounting bracket) for cheap chinese bicycle red lights that always love to break.
This is a copy of original holder, but slightly modified - I made it a little thicker on the most weak places. There are two different versions. The bigger one is the same as original holder. Original bicycle lights come with rubber inserts, so you can choose your desired tube thickness. Smaller version can be used without rubbers (smaller diameter possible) - very useful if you lost your rubber inserts or don't want to use them for some reason.
When slicing remember to put more for shell thickness - when mounting on bike you will bend it, and thin part can easily break.

title: "Nano Sim" to Sim Adapter (Tight Fit for iPhone 3GS)

description.text:
I made a new Nano Sim to Sim Adapter, because i needed one with a very thight fit. The Nano Sim (T-Mobile, Germany) snaps into palce and stays in place - i even if i drop the adapter. The adapter has also a tight fit in the iPhone 3GS Sim-Draw.
I printed many versions, to make it fit perfectly (for my Nano Sim and iPhone). A Tip for beginners (like me)
The smal flaps, that hold the Nano Sim in place, are only 0.2 mm thick. Therefore, you have to print the first layer with a max. thickness of 0.2 mm or these Flaps will not be printed (as i had to learn on this project).

A 300 sized quadcopter for 3D printing. This quad has been designed for use with 6" props and a Q-brain esc. You don't have to use a Q-Brain, but it integrates into the frame nicely and cleans up the wiring without a power distribution board. Arms are unique and carry 2 motors each, which increases strength and simplifies body attachment.
I didn't bother to design a recording camera mount at this point because I don't want the extra weight/cost and my Dominator googles have a built in DVR. An easy top plate mod if I change my mind. Note: Added "split frame" file for those with less than an 10" bed. Post printing gluing required. BOM: Printed parts (see instructions) Electronics:
Flight Controller with side pins such as a CC3D
Rx such as X6R
ESC such as Q-Brain 4x20 or 4x25, 4S capable
Low Battery Buzzer
Motors with 16x19 bolt pattern, 2204/06/08 sized, 1900-2300kV
XT60 female for ESC to Q-brain power leads
2mm bullet connectors for Q-Brain to motors x12
Battery, 1300-2200mah, 4S, XT60 connector x2-6
Camera, 25x25 board in case (or smaller)
VTx, such as fatshark 250mW or 600mW
Googles such as Fatshark Dominators (with Rx module & batteries)
Antenna such as fatshark spironet or bluebeam ultra (pair needed)
Radio such as taranis X9D+
Battery charger such as IMAX B6 Hardware
m3x45mm hex bolts x12
M3x40mm hex bolts x6 + spares (landing legs)
M3x8mm for motors x16
M3x10mm for camera x1
M3x16-20mm for RX holder
M3 nyloc nuts x20
M3 washers x26
Household elastics to hold motor wires, could also just tape them
Velcro strips (my preference for all electronic except FC)
Velcro strap for battery
Foam or gel pad for flight controller (optional)
Shrink Wrap for wiring and holding Rx antenna Other:
Props!
6030 if you are starting out (still can really move!)
6040 or 6045 otherwise
M5 nyloc nuts and washers for props (unless you have multi direction threads or a different size mount)

You need a bed bigger than 200x200 (8"x8") for the top and bottom plates. DO NOT PRINT PLATES AND ARMS WITH 100% INFILL, you will be unnecessarily heavy. Need 2 arms, 1 top plate, 1 bottom plate, 2 22mm pegs, 2 center shields, 1 camera shield, 1 Rx holder For a 0.4mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer heights I'd recommend:
Arms
6 bottom, 8 top, 5 perimeters, 20-30% rectilinear infill
Top and Bottom Plate
2 bottom, 3 top, rectilinear
8-12 perimeters, 15-25% honeycomb infill
Material: I used PLA for the body and PHA for the arms and landing leg tips. However, I would recommend PETG if you can print it. If you do go with the fatshark 600mw vtx:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865127

description.text:
Another weekend and I have reworked everything except for the arms and the nose mounted weapons pod. The original file is now just a thought. Tons more details have been added. Increased the size of the feet. Buffed up the lower leg and added struts. Every time I get into any design it is a learning process and I get flooded with new ideas. How can I make this little detail, what if I do this for better motion mechanic. There is just not enough time to puke out all of my concepts. At this point I feel like flushing much of this design and starting over completely. TinkerCAD is now crashing on this model. Far too many layers. Inspiration found here.
http://www.camospecs.com/Miniature.asp?Id=6921
and here
http://mwomercs.com/forums/topic/199695-next-mech-i-wanna-see/page__fromsearch__1 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4PdyrVBtzyV

comments.text: Fully broken down and redesigned and each part should be ready to print. The joints are TinkerPlay and I am hopeful that when placed into a design like this they will still flex enough to clip together.

title: Magnetic Button Mount for C1-Glass 3D Glasses

description.text: Magnetic button mount for C1-Glass 3D glasses. These Google Cardboard-like goggles do not come with a button, so this mount is designed to attach to the arm and give it a button. You will need a 3/4" dia x 3/16" thickness ceramic magnet to glue in the round hole, as well as a 3/4" dia x 1/8" thickness neodynium ring or countersunk magnet to act as the sliding button. Small changes were made on 6/9/15 to improve printability.

With Makerfaire coming up I was thinking about how I will be able to recognize other 3D printer operators. Since we all don't usually go by our usernames I thought about how we could use our machines to recognize each other. So I created this nifty little 3D printer operator badge. So print one out and wear it to Makerfaire to show your pride for 3D printing. This is also a great conversation starter! Plus it is in the Makerfaire colors!! Wear one to Makerfaire if you 3D print!!!

If you printed it in blue skip the second step.
  • Print one out in any color (preferably blue).
  • Spray Paint Blue and Let Dry.
  • Use a RED FINE point sharpie and color in the words.
  • Install Safety Pin in the rear with Super Glue.
  • Wear to Makerfaire!!!
  • Enjoy!

Perfect for tabletop RPG encounters! I did my best to remove the original file's spikes and just create a simple barricade. I couldn't remove them fully, but I was able to add a plank that allows you to stand minis up on it. The plank may take a few tries, and I would recommend using hot glue to attach it rather then Krazy Glue like I used. Just be sure to use your minis to mark what height you want it BEFORE gluing! I almost made that mistake myself. It doesn't need any special settings, just use your defaults. Though I would recommend checking out this thing for some great accessories for it. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635741 It can be used with OpenForge, but I URGE YOU to make sure you have it scaled to your liking, because I print my tiles at 120% along the x & y to allow for 30mm minis. As a result, any time I convert something to be printed, I load in a few parts of terrain and scale them to size before scaling it to match. Meaning I don't put much emphasis on proper scaling prior to the conversion step.

description.text: Fits 1 (one) Raspberry Pi in a compatible mount Brick. This mount is intended to a hold Raspberry Pi Model B Revision 2.0 "Like US" https://www.facebook.com/badbrick The case itself can be stand alone or mounted. The (4) "+" mount holes also fit the Lego + shafts in technic kits. This base plate is also compatible with Adafruit's Low-profile microSD card adapter for Raspberry Pi. Just clip out the support peg for the normal SD card. The picture above shows the case base with the RasPi and that adapter. Its much better then having a big SD card sticking out. If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at badbrick.com/catalog

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings:
Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the little larger prints fuse better. All other defaults are the same.

http://youtu.be/sWD4rVweHvo This is the new version of the caterpillator. This version tries to overcome the problems found in version 1.0 and also it has become completely parametrizable. More documentation of this robot can be found at http://mrgroup.dyndns.org/mrgroup/doku.php?id=robots:orugator:orugator_v1.1
It is especially recommended to have a look at that page in order to understand better the notation of the parameters used in the different files of openscad since it includes the drafts of the different parts. Update
I have added the stl files that we are actually printing :) For the moment we have one wheel and some links surrounding it
http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:9532 Update 21/5
We've started to print the robot. Here it goes a video of the links and the wheels
http://youtu.be/NoXAF5WsLn0

-Download all the scad files.
-Open the one called Parametric_bot.1.1.scad with OpenScad In that file you can choose which part of the robot you want to generate according to the dimensions of the wheel. Read the comments in the file to know which parameters you must introduce.
  • The pack for the batteries can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079
    -The U piece and the holder for the batteries are taken from the miniskybot chassis by Obijuan:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7989
    • All the stl files that are uploaded correspond to the pieces that we have printed for the caterpillator that we are making.

comments.text: Hi everyone,
comments.author: pasquinade

comments.text: link.stl and 4links.stl : tracks are different in size. Which one are you using?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Nevermind.
Hey Olalla
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: All the team is currently on holidays, so the project is on hold till September, when all of us will be together again...
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Nevermind
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Hey Olalla
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Hi!
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Hey Olalla/Avalero
comments.author: Olalla

comments.text: Tracks were jumping off because of a bad design on the chain. Once the chain has improved the track remains on its place. Nevertheless they will be printed, as they will be useful for more rough terrains.
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Well, the printer is shared with a group of people, so the priority was to print enough pieces to prove that the design worked -which can be done without the outer wheels-. Once the caterpillator was printed then other projects got the priority (the unitrack http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7640http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... for example is trying to evolve into a bi-track :-P ).
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Olalla is on holidays, so I'll take the freedom to answer :P she may add what she wants when she will be online
comments.author: AgeingHippy

comments.text: Now: this is REALLY awesome! It turned up better than I expected! And seems quite rugged: the moment in which the robot falls in the video is great: It shows that it can survive a little drop, and opens a new idea: a robot that can drive upside down!
comments.author: WarrantyVoider

comments.text: Hi! And now it's time to add some intelligence :)
comments.author: WarrantyVoider

comments.text: Each link of the track has a drop of hard silicone plastic, without it, it did not track well, but after adding it (it took 5 minutes with a silicon gun) as you can see on he video it works perfectly. It can even turnover when colliding with a wall. We still have to check how it works under differential driving, as sliding is required.
comments.author: WarrantyVoider

comments.text: Like you design and project. Say, not to cause trouble but, I saw a use for something and I see a change on your design because of a Problem? You are designing sides to your tracks. Were you throwing tracks? I've seen a use for a part on thingiverse that I'm printing and trying to alter to better fit its intended use but, it would be very good as tracks. The benefit of the design is that it is deep - less likely to be thrown. And by its inherent design/nature will grip the turning wheel's gear teeth while driving and then relax as it traverses to the next gear wheel. See the picture of my printed example of Saminvents' links. See: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7469http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: Aw, on further thought I see why you have raised exterior wheel rims. Easy traverse on hard surfaces and the tracks are ready for soft ground when the robot sinks and needs more traction? Yes?
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: I like the idea of raising the wheels in order to keep the wheel in contact when the surface is flat while the track will only actuate when the surface is rough or with obstacles... but, the "programmers" have the control!! ;-)... maybe I will make my own derivative  :-P
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: We should leave the orugator and the unitrack together and see if they like each other, their offspring would be something similar at what you want  :-P
comments.author: avalero

comments.text: Naw, the links are the ones in contact with the ground at every time, the sides were designed -as you originally thought- because the our track was being thrown away (it had to do also because we had to fit the back axis with screws and their heads were displacing the tracked wheels and that made pression to the track).
comments.author: bstott

comments.text: wow!! I cannot wait too see it printed and see it moving. Really awesome. Great jog!!
comments.author: avalero

comments.text: Great job!!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Thanks. I wait impatiently for your modules to include the sensors in the robot  :-P

comments.text: What is the cable connected to the GPIO? Pins on top do?
comments.author: onezero1010101

comments.text: I connect to the GPIO to provide the Pi with power from the ATX power supply's 5V standby, switch the ATX on/off with its PWR_ON, and control the RGB lighting strip's color. All these run through a proto board I put in the base of the printer with a fuse for the power input and a darlington array for the power supply switching and RGB control.

description.text:
Helps stop the doors from hitting the walls(or mirror in my case) and no kid can brake it by stepping on it! This is the product of a trial and error when looking for the right material. title: Robo3D Low Profile fan duct mount with support

description.text:
A remix of thing:431160 that adds support so it will print properly using the default MatterControl software that comes with the Robo3D R1 printer.  Even if you enable "generate support material" in MatterControl it seems to think it's not needed (under default configuration, at least) and so this design lets you print it regardless.  
This replaces the bracket from thing:431160 and works with the original duct.  
The supports are a little thicker than normal but can be removed with a hobby knife or blade.
Print, remove the supports and then use it with the duct part of thing:431160.

Here's a Magpul FMG-9 I've been working on for a while now. It's a work in progress and isn't an exact copy or fully complete, but i tried to get it as close to the original as possible. I figured I might start and someone else could perfect it!. I've always been fascinated with its design and haven't been able to find a decent model of it. It should be printable, I ran it through slicer and everything checked out. Not sure if its airsoft capable, but the dimensions are roughly the same as the airsoft version. Ill upload the parts separately when i get a chance. Lemme know what you guys think! Thanks! PS.
(this is just a novelty, not a weapon) (Update: I haven't really been working on this but thanks to qtronix for splitting up the files! completely forgot to! Ill add a charging handle and all other parts I missed asap)

comments.text: The back of the receiver is actually open, from my knowledge. The FMG is built around a Glock, so the slide reciprocates through and into the stock. When the gun is folded, the panel is hinged on the top of the receiver closes and fills those openings in the receiver and stock. This applies both on the airsoft and real steel versions.
